speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues at the Federal Reserve and I are dedicated to serving the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do this by steadfastly pursuing the goals Congress has given us: maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to making the best decisions we can based on facts and objective analysis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today we decided to lower interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I will explain shortly, we took this step to help keep the U.S. economy strong in the face of some notable developments and to provide insurance against ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy has continued to perform well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are into the 11th year of this economic expansion, and the baseline outlook remains favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy grew at a 2½ percent pace in the first half of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending—supported by a strong job market, rising incomes, and solid consumer confidence—has been the key driver of growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, business investment and exports have weakened amid falling manufacturing output.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The main reasons appear to be slower growth abroad and trade policy developments—two sources of uncertainty that we’ve been monitoring all year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the middle of last year, the global growth outlook has weakened, notably in Europe and China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Additionally, a number of geopolitical risks, including Brexit, remain unresolved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Trade policy tensions have waxed and waned, and elevated uncertainty is weighing on U.S. investment and exports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our business contacts around the country have been telling us that uncertainty about trade policy has discouraged them from investing in their businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business fixed investment posted a modest decline in the second quarter, and recent indicators point to continued softness.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, with household spending remaining on a solid footing and with supportive financial conditions, we expect the economy to continue to expand at a moderate rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 18, 2019 As seen from FOMC participants’ most recent projections, the median expectation for real GDP Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL growth remains near 2 percent this year and next before edging down toward its estimated longer-run value.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The job market remains strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has been near half-century lows for a year and a half, and job gains have remained solid in recent months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pace of job gains has eased this year, but we had expected some slowing after last year’s strong pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation in the labor force by people in their prime working years has been increasing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And wages have been rising, particularly for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that many who have struggled to find work are now getting opportunities to add new and better chapters to their lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This underscores, for us, the importance of sustaining the expansion so that the strong job market reaches more of those left behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect the job market to remain strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median of participants’ projections for the unemployment rate remains below 4 percent over the next several years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation continues to run below our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months through July, total PCE inflation was 1.4 percent and core inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, was 1.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We still expect inflation to rise to 2 percent; the median projection is 1.9 percent this year and 2 percent in 2021.1 However, inflation pressures clearly remain muted, and indicators of longer-term inflation expectations are at the lower end of their historical ranges.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are mindful that continued below-target inflation could lead to an unwelcome downward slide in longer-term inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, as we say in our postmeeting statement, we continue to see sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent 1 Chair Powell intended to say that the median projection is 1.9 percent next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 18, 2019 objective as most likely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While this has been our outlook for quite some time, our views about Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the path of interest rates that will best achieve these outcomes have changed significantly over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, weakness in global growth and trade policy uncertainty have weighed on the economy and pose ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These factors, in conjunction with muted inflation pressures, have led us to shift our views about appropriate monetary policy over time toward a lower path for the federal funds rate, and this shift has supported the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, this is the role of monetary policy—to adjust interest rates to maintain a strong labor market and keep inflation near our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today’s decision to lower the federal funds rate target by ¼ percent, to 1.75 percent to 2 percent, is appropriate in light of the global developments I mentioned as well as muted inflation pressures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since our last meeting, we have seen additional signs of weakness abroad and a resurgence of trade policy tensions, including the imposition of additional tariffs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed has no role in the formulation of trade policy, but we do take into account anything that could materially affect the economy relative to our employment and inflation goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The future course of monetary policy will depend on how the economy evolves and what developments imply for the economic outlook and risks to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have often said that policy is not on a preset course, and that is certainly the case today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I have noted, the baseline economic outlook remains positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The projections of appropriate policy show that participants generally anticipate only modest changes in the federal funds rate over the next couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, those views are merely forecasts and, as always, will evolve with the arrival of new information.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me say a few words about our monetary policy operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Funding pressures in money markets were elevated this week, and the effective federal funds rate rose above the top September 18, 2019 of its target range yesterday.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While these issues are important for market functioning and market Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL participants, they have no implications for the economy or the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This upward pressure emerged as funds flowed from the private sector to the Treasury to meet corporate tax payments and settle purchases of Treasury securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To counter these pressures, we conducted overnight repurchase operations yesterday and again today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These temporary operations were effective in relieving funding pressures, and we expect the federal funds rate to move back into the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, as we have done in the past, we made a technical adjustment to the interest rate paid on required and excess reserve balances, setting it 20 basis points below the top of the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In a related action, we also adjusted the rate on the overnight repurchase facility to 5 basis points below the bottom of the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to monitor market developments and will conduct operations as necessary to foster trading in the federal funds market at rates within the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Consistent with our decision earlier this year to continue to implement monetary policy in an ample-reserves regime, we will, over time, provide a sufficient supply of reserves so that frequent operations are not required.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To summarize, we are fully committed to pursuing our goals of maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the Committee contemplates the future path of the target range for the federal funds rate, it will continue to monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 18, 2019 Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Marty Crutsinger with the Associated Press.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Mr. Chairman, when you cut rates in July, you characterized it as a “midcycle adjustment.” Is that still your view of what’s happening?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you can see from our policy statement and from the SEP, we see a favorable economic outlook, with continued moderate growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, that view is consistent with those of many other forecasters.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you can see, FOMC participants generally think that these positive economic outcomes will be achieved with modest adjustments to the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the last press conference, I pointed to two episodes in, I guess, 1995 and 1998 as examples of such an approach, which was successful in both of those instances.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As our statement also highlights, though, there are risks to this positive outlook due particularly to weak global growth and trade developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if the economy does turn down, then a more extensive sequence of rate cuts could be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t see that—it’s not what we expect—but we would certainly follow that path if it became appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In other words, as we say in our statement, we will continue to monitor these developments closely, and we will act as appropriate to help ensure that the expansion remains on track.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: [Inaudible remark] I’m sorry.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: Rich Miller with Bloomberg.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: Taking the statement, your opening remarks, and the SEP, I’m just wondering what kind of message we should take from this.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: Do you still—does the FOMC—is it safe to say the FOMC still has an easing bias or not?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the idea of having a bias is something that was a longtime practice, and we don’t actually have that practice anymore, so I can’t really adopt it right here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, I’ll respond to your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we did—we made one decision today, and September 18, 2019 that decision was to lower the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe that action is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL appropriate to promote our objectives, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be highly data dependent, as always.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decisions are going to depend on the implications of incoming information for the outlook, and I would also say, as we often do, that we’re not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re going to look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be carefully looking at economic data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sometimes the path ahead is clear and sometimes less so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re going to be looking carefully, meeting by meeting, at the full range of information, and we’re going to assess the appropriate stance of policy as we go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I said, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: If I could just follow up, you’ve also said that the favorable outlook is predicated on financial conditions, and the financial conditions are in turn predicated on an outlook for Fed policy—in this case, further cuts.

speaker: RICHARD MILLER
sentence: Wouldn’t that suggest that you should be inclined to—if you want those financial conditions and that favorable outlook to come about, you should be inclined to cut?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, what we do going forward is very much going to depend, Rich, on the flow of data and information.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen—you know, if you look at the things we’re monitoring, particularly global growth and trade developments, global growth has continued to weaken.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s weakened since our last meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Trade developments have been up and down and then up, I guess—or back up, perhaps—over the course of this intermeeting period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In any case, they’ve been quite volatile.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do see those risks as actually more heightened now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be watching that carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also going to be watching the U.S. data quite carefully, and we’ll have to make an assessment as we go.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I know you’re trying to speak for the Committee when you do these press conferences, September 18, 2019 but the Committee is clearly divided right now, at least about the outlook and the appropriate Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL policy path.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Some people think you need to wait and see the labor market and the consumer crack or weaken further before acting more aggressively, and some people think that by the time that happens, you’ll need to do even more aggressive action to arrest a downturn.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Where do you stand on this?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, let me just say, on the general point of diverse perspectives, you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sometimes the—and there have been many of those times in my now almost eight years at the Fed, many times when the direction is relatively clear and it’s relatively easy to reach unanimity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a time of difficult judgments and, as you can see, disparate perspectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I really do think that’s nothing but healthy, and so I see a benefit in having those diverse perspectives, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So your question, though, is?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: This is to your own view, because the data is, to some extent, lagged, especially when you have these risks on the horizon, and the markets obviously think that these risks could materialize more than what you and your colleagues are projecting in the dot plot today.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: So, I wonder, where are your own views about the tension between risk management, which implies some degree of data independence, and this idea of being data dependent?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll try to get at that this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that the idea that if you see trouble approaching on the horizon, you steer away from it if you can—I think that’s a good idea in principle, and I think history teaches us that it’s better to be proactive in adjusting policy if you can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think applying that principle in a particular situation is where the challenge comes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I told you where the Committee—the bulk of the Committee is going, meeting by meeting, and I think the main takeaway is that this is a Committee that has shifted its policy stance repeatedly, September 18, 2019 consistently, through the course of the year to support economic activity as it has felt that it’s Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the beginning of the year we were looking at further rate increases, then we were patient, and then we cut once, then we cut again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you’ve seen us being willing to move based on data, based on the evolving risk picture, and I have no reason to think that will change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think—but it will continue to be data dependent, and depend—data includes the evolving risk picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s where I am, and that’s where I think the bulk of the Committee is.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, I wonder if you’re—oh, sorry.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I’ve only done this a dozen—a lot of times.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I wonder if you’re concerned about how the Federal Reserve operated through the recent liquidity crunch in markets.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: We talked to many traders who said the tax date payment was known well in advance.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: There were several reports of people pointing to September as a potential crunch time.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You closed Monday at the top end of the fed funds rate.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Tuesday came along, and there wasn’t an operation until nine o’clock and no announcement until—of a second operation until four o’clock in the afternoon.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Was the Fed listening to markets well ahead of time, going back a year when there were blowouts in the overnight rate at year-end and the turn of the year?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Are you concerned about how, for example, the New York Fed operated through this?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so I would say I doubt that anyone is closer to and has more invested in carefully following the—you know, the behavior of these markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we were well aware of the—you know, the tax payments and also of the settlement of the large bond purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we were very much waiting for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we didn’t expect—the response to that was stronger than we expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, our sense is that it surprised market participants a lot, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, people were writing about this and publishing stories about it weeks ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It wasn’t a surprise, but it was—it was a stronger response September 18, 2019 than—certainly than we expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, no, I’m not concerned about that, to answer your Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can go on a little bit about how we’re looking at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Why don’t I do that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, it doesn’t—we don’t see this as having any implications for the broader economy or for the economic outlook, nor for our ability to control rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The strains in the money markets reflect forces that we saw coming, and they just had a bigger effect than I think most folks anticipated—strong demand for cash to purchase Treasuries and pay corporate taxes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We took appropriate actions to address those pressures, to keep the fed funds rate within the target range, and those measures were successful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we experience another episode of pressures in money markets, we have the tools to address those pressures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will not hesitate to use them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And since we’re talking about this, let me take a step back and say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Earlier in the year, as you will all recall, after careful study over a period of years, actually, the Committee announced the decision to implement monetary policy in an ample-reserves regime.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve been operating in that regime for a full decade.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it works well to implement our rate decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The main hallmark of that regime is that we use adjustments in our administered rates—the IOER and RRP rates—to keep the fed fund rates in the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s designed specifically so that we do not expect to be conducting frequent open market operations for that purpose.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, going forward, we’re going to be very closely monitoring market developments and assessing their implications for the appropriate level of reserves, and we’re going to be assessing, you know, the question of when it will be appropriate to resume the organic growth of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m sure we’ll be revisiting that question during this intermeeting period and certainly at our next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 18, 2019 Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL STEVE LIESMAN.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Could I just follow up here quickly?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Do you think you’ve underestimated the amount of reserves necessary for the banking system?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve always said that it’s—that the level is uncertain, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s something we’ve tried to be very clear about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as you know, we’ve invested lots of time talking to many of the large holders of reserves to assess their—what they say is their demand for reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try to assess what that is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve tried to combine all of that together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We put it out so the public can react to it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, yes, there’s real uncertainty, and it is certainly possible that we will need to resume the organic growth of the balance sheet earlier than we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s always been a possibility, and it certainly is now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, we’ll be looking at this carefully in coming days and taking it up at the next meeting.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: Brendan Greeley with the Financial Times.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: Earlier this year—or, actually, in September, the Governors’ Board put out a research paper looking—trying to quantify trade uncertainty.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: And it suggested that it could drag through the business investment channel on growth as much as a percentage point over the course of the next year.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: How much confidence do you have in the Fed’s ability to estimate the real effects of trade uncertainty?

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: And if you have confidence in that paper, it would seem to suggest a—sort of a more aggressively dovish path than the one that you’ve chosen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think to provide a little context, Fed economists do research all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s generally of very high quality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s their research.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not an official finding of the Federal Reserve Board or the Federal Reserve System.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just—and, by the way, they put it out for public review so that you can see their econometrics, so you can see all of it—their whole work is exposed to critique by the whole profession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a great tradition that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, what this particular piece of work did is, it went after measuring trade September 18, 2019 policy uncertainty through a couple of channels, including concerning tariffs, also concerning the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL threat of more tariffs, and it looked deeply at the data to try to assess the effects on output.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And while I would say, directly answering your question, there’s real uncertainty around these—around these effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a $22 trillion economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To try to isolate the effects of certain things is very challenging, but we do the best we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and this piece of research found significant effects, and that’s frankly consistent with a number of other research projects that economists have undertaken.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also consistent with what we’ve been hearing in the Beige Book.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I mean, I think if you take a step back from that, we do feel that trade uncertainty is having an effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see it in weak business investment, weak exports—hard to quantify it precisely, though.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Hi, Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: I was struck by the sort of anchored median federal funds rate here through 2020, and that in comparison to the fact that you now have sort of three very discrete groups of opinions around where the fed funds rate is heading.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: And I wondered, is it fair to say that the—those opinions have become sort of firmer in their conviction, and that it’s going to take some sort of real material change in the outlook now for that to move in either direction?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re asking specifically about 2020?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Well, the fact that this—the fed funds rate is now seen as not moving through 2020 suggests to me that these opinions are pretty—pretty well anchored right now in those groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, honestly, I think it’s hard to have hardened expectations about where rate policy is going to be a year from now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the closer you get to the current day, the more confidence you can have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But even then, knowing where the—knowing what the September 18, 2019 data will say and the way geopolitical events and other events are going to evolve in the next Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL 90 days and the implications of that for the economy, I would say there’s a lot of uncertainty around that.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Fair enough, but if— CHAIR POWELL.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Particularly, if you look at 2020, I think the use of this is, individual participants write down their forecasts.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: It should give you a sense of how people are thinking about the likely path of the economy and the appropriate path for monetary policy in that individual person’s thinking, and I think that’s a good thing to know.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: I think I’d be very reluctant to look at it as hardened views or a prediction, really.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: But just to follow up, if I could.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: There were a number of arguments in July around the reason for cutting rates.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Have any of those gotten substantially weaker or changed around the table?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, well, I think, if you look at the U.S.—look at the U.S. economy, the U.S. economy has generally performed roughly as expected—roughly: The consumer is spending at a healthy clip, I’d say business fixed investment and exports have weakened further, and I’d say the manufacturing PMI suggests more weakness ahead.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market is still strong, though, so generally that is the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think if you look at—the global economy, I think, has weakened further in the EU and China, and I think, you know, trade policy developments have been a big mover of markets and of sentiment during that intermeeting period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s why I think what’s—that’s what’s happened over the intermeeting period, and, you know, different people around the table have different perspectives as you obviously know.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek with the New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I’m just curious on your balance sheet point.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK

sentence: But we do have a very powerful tool which can counteract weakness, to some extent, by supporting demand through sound monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think our policy tools support economic activity through fairly well-understood channels: by reducing interest September 18, 2019 burden and encouraging consumer purchase of durables, of homes, and other interest-sensitive Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL items; by creating broadly more accommodative financial conditions, which support spending and also investment by businesses; and also by boosting household and business confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I don’t want to be heard to say that our tools don’t have an effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: There’s no simple bottom-line answer where I can say, yes, I’ve got it for you here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think what we need to do is to try to look through the volatility and react to the underlying forces, the underlying things that are happening that are relevant to our mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t—we have nothing to do with setting trade policy or negotiating trade agreements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what we are looking for through all of the data, all the events that are going on around the world, we’ll be looking at, you know, the evolving geopolitical events, we’ll be looking at global growth, we’ll be looking at trade policy uncertainty.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking for things that are affecting the outlook for the U.S. economy, particularly the outlook as it relates to maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all of those things in principle can affect the achievement of our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s an unusual situation, because, you know, the U.S. economy itself—the largest part of it, the consumer part of it—is in strong shape.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The manufacturing part, less so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We chose to—after we got to the effective lower bound, we chose to do a lot of aggressive forward guidance and also large-scale asset purchases, and those were the two unconventional monetary policy tools that we used extensively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 18, 2019 Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL DON LEE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: So, in terms of how our rate cuts will affect the real economy, first, we think monetary policy works with, as Friedman said, long and variable lags.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we think that lower interest rates will reduce interest burden for borrowers, so that interest-sensitive things like housing and durable goods and other things like that—cars—it supports purchases of those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also think there’s a confidence channel.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see—you see household and business confidence turn up when financial conditions become more accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, through all of those channels, monetary policy works.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t, you know, precisely the right tool for every single possible negative thing that can happen to the economy, but, nonetheless, it broadly works, and, you know, we’re going to use the tool we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if it comes to it, we’ll use all of our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: DON LEE

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll—we’ll use our tools to offset negative—that’s really the job of monetary policy, is, to the extent it can, to offset, you know, things that drive us away from maximum employment and stable prices.

sentence: Chair Powell, are you worried that the low interest rates are adding to, or could create a bubble of, September 18, 2019 consumer and corporate debt that could make it more difficult for, especially, consumers to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL recover from the next recession or survive the next recession?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so, if you look at—if you actually look at households, households are in very strong shape.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: All of that comes from the private sector, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL but also from more of the kinds of things that can be done with fiscal policy.

sentence: Over the long run, we can’t really affect the growth rate of the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The potential growth rate of the United States is not a function of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a function of other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—I try to be clear about that, and so—but, ultimately, fiscal—fiscal authorities will do what they seem—deem appropriate.

speaker: SAMIRA HUSSAIN
sentence: Samira Hussain, BBC News.

speaker: SAMIRA HUSSAIN
sentence: Mr. Trump has been a very vocal critic of you and your colleagues, recently calling you “boneheads” and just now has called you a “terrible communicator.” How do you respond to these criticisms?

speaker: SAMIRA HUSSAIN
sentence: And any regrets to have this many press conferences?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to change my practice here today of not responding to comments or addressing comments made by elected officials.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will just say that I continue to believe that the independence of the Federal Reserve from direct political control has served the public well over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I assure you that my colleagues and I will continue to conduct monetary policy without regard to political considerations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to use our best judgment based on facts, evidence, and objective analysis in pursuing our goals, and that’s what I have to say on it.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi, Chairman Powell.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Brian Cheung with Yahoo Finance.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Thanks for taking my question.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: As we saw with falling yields, at least up until the beginning of this month, there’s been a lot of demand for U.S. Treasuries, and even that was partly maybe to blame for the liquidity crunch in repo markets that we saw this week.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: I mean, does the Fed have concerns over the impacts of a global glut for U.S. debt?

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Is that a conversation that you also September 18, 2019 have with Treasury Secretary Mnuchin—about what the proper way to maybe address some of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the challenges down the road with that type of, kind of, heavy interest globally?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not really, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really—that’s really Treasury’s job and Congress’s job, in terms of, well, there’s how much to spend, and how big the deficits are, and then there’s how to finance it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, none of that really calls for advice from the Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We take—we take fiscal policy pretty much as exogenous to our work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, that doesn’t stop us, from time to time, from saying that we think it’s important that the U.S. fiscal picture return to a sustainable footing, and, you know, right now it’s not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s been the case for a long time, and that’s something we will have to address, and a good time to do it is when the economy is strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we limit ourselves to high-level statements like that.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Hi, Heather Long from the Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Mr. Chairman, in your view, is there any risk to the United States having much higher interest rates than Europe and Japan and other parts of the world?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Is there any risk to the U.S. economy to that divergence or any risk to the global economy?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, so I guess I would say it this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Global capital markets are highly integrated, and, you know, our rates—our long rates are definitely being pulled down by the very, very low rates that are abroad.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the way I would characterize it is this: that low rates abroad are a symbol—or a sign, rather, of weak global growth, expectations of low inflation, low growth, and, you know, just kind of a lack of policy space to move against or ideas about how to break out of that low equilibrium.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, that has implications for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we—in a world where economies and financial markets are tightly integrated, that matters for the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s going to pull down U.S. rates, and U.S. financial conditions can tighten because of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I think we put all—all of that goes into our thinking and into our September 18, 2019 models.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do understand how the—you know, how the international sector interfaces with the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We take that into account in setting our interest rate policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.
